video_path: C:\Users\chris\Dropbox\Scripts\clip-video\brands\KCD-UK\videos\Jos van Schouten - The Real CI CD is Communication, Iteration, Coffee, and Donuts.mp4
text: All right So I'm Jost and I want to talk about real CICD communication coffee and donuts or basically what I tell junior engineers but in a five minute version So this is how we're often sold on CICD It's a magical conveyor belt You have your pipeline you commit your code everything's magic except not really right We've got problems like this You want to do a deploy but you can't because you're waiting for someone or someone sneaks in a last minute PR Or maybe you do deploy and it breaks production And I'd argue none of these are technical problems It's a problem coming from inside of the organization Tools are not going to fix broken communication right It's about silence It's tools can automate flow but it's culture that determines if flow actually works Communication has to be continuous too Otherwise in the end you'll stall your And you see this with the best performing teams They're highly visible They have high communication And you see this from the Dora report Dora Institute report for instance Those teams with high collaboration they recover faster but also they fail less often And they do this by baking in conversation Chat ops highly visible reviews They catch problems early They do all the things that you learn about in Agile or in DevOps but it matters for a reason Because if you don't you get drift And drift isn't about laziness It's about Slack going quiet during deploys It's about people saying stuff like this Oh no that's fails in staging but it's fine in prod That doesn't happen But yeah if you say this you normalize bad behavior If you see this happening you should inspect your pipeline If you run into problems like this I'd argue that's a bad pattern if you hear this in a Drift is people saying bad code instead of why didn't the pipeline catch this It's when language shifts It's basically when things or people get blamed And we don't fix this by blame but we fix this by feedback Like Mr Miyagi teaches in the Karate Kid you need continuous feedback Feedback repetition matters Feedback repeated often practice into confidence and turns confidence into resilience Observability that's kind of part of that You do a successful deploy and there's silence Does that mean it's stable or does that mean it's invisible You need more than just a thumbs up You need active feedback Another bad anti pattern I want to mention quickly is this guy Maybe nobody owns the pipeline This guy shows up in the end at some point and he always will Because management thinks someone needs to sign off And you get ceremony and you don't have accountability So watch out for him And don't get me wrong on blamelessness It doesn't mean it's soft We still do postmortems We still do all the things to inspect the pipeline to inspect production to make sure there's resilience We all know tech depth slows you down Culture depth does the exact same thing Every time you allow for drift for ceremony or silence you're building culture depth Because in the end what matters is whether your team can recover learn adapt And culture shows up in those metrics It shows up in recovery time lead time and visibility There's a reason for the four measure flow in the end So yeah this is where we started out with the perfect conveyor belt Except you know frosting gets spilled the belt breaks we send in engineers they talk about the problem they fix the problem And that whole thing is what ships in the end not just code Because like Homer Simpson knows donuts are not just fuel they're feedback Thank you
